title: Present Simple
examples: She works in a bank.
They play tennis every Sunday.
commonMistakes: Forgetting -s with he/she/it
Using Present Continuous for permanent facts

title: Present Continuous
whenToUse: actions happening now or around now
examples: I am reading now.
They are not watching TV at the moment.
commonMistakes: Using base verb instead of verb-ing
Missing am/is/are

title: Present Perfect
whenToUse: past actions with a present result or life experience
examples: We have finished our homework.
He has never seen snow.
commonMistakes: Using past simple instead of past participle
Using a specific finished past time with present perfect

title: Present Perfect Continuous
whenToUse: actions that started in the past and continue now
examples: She has been studying for three hours.
I have been waiting since 9 a.m.
commonMistakes: Using present continuous for long-duration actions from the past
Missing been in the structure

title: Past Simple
examples: I went home yesterday.
She finished work at 6 p.m.
commonMistakes: Using base verb after subject
Mixing past simple with present perfect time markers

title: Past Continuous
whenToUse: an action in progress at a specific past time
examples: They were watching TV when I called.
I was working all evening.
commonMistakes: Using was with plural subjects
Using past simple for interrupted background action

title: Past Perfect
whenToUse: the earlier of two past actions
examples: By the time I arrived, they had left.
She had already eaten when we got home.
commonMistakes: Using past simple for both actions when sequence matters
Using have/has instead of had

title: Past Perfect Continuous
examples: He had been working there for five years before he moved.
They had been waiting for an hour before the bus came.
commonMistakes: Dropping been from had been + verb-ing
Using past continuous when earlier duration should be emphasized

title: Future Simple
examples: I think it will rain tomorrow.
She will help you with your project.
commonMistakes: Using will + verb-ing for simple prediction
Using present simple for spontaneous decisions

title: Future Continuous
whenToUse: action that will be in progress at a future time
examples: This time tomorrow, we will be flying to Rome.
At 8 p.m., he will be studying.
commonMistakes: Using will + base verb instead of will be + verb-ing
Using for completed actions by a future deadline

title: Future Perfect
whenToUse: actions completed before a future point
examples: By next year, I will have finished my degree.
They will have built the bridge by June.
commonMistakes: Using future simple when completion before a deadline is needed
Using will had instead of will have

title: Future Perfect Continuous
whenToUse: duration up to a specific future moment
examples: By noon, she will have been working for six hours.
Next month, we will have been living here for ten years.
commonMistakes: Using future perfect when ongoing duration is intended
Skipping been in will have been + verb-ing
